Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c one more thing I want to explain. In BTC internals, "dust" is defined with "<" operator. Less than. There is no lower limit, in internals. There is no definition of "spam", in the internals spam is included in the definition of "dust"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: So that means, purely mathematically, all spam attacks are dust attacks, but not all dust attacks are  spam attacks

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and some are de-anon'ing, some aren't. And you can do both at the same time

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I will try to explain this as best I can to the lovely people on Twitter

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: actually if you send a bigger amount, it is more likely to deanonymize

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: as it is more likely bitcoind logic includes it in the transaction

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but the simple workaround is to just combine all dust from the same address to the same address

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then 0 information is leaked!

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just free money as long as the increased txfee is not more expensive than the dust

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it would divulge when you did this merging and if you are under surveillance at the router level, maybe your ip can be deanonymized, but that can be done independently of the dust attack

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @CHMEX starting to get raw data about shielded transactions/payments. I need to make the RPC return data in a nice json format, and use the basic stats to derive more useful metrics/etc. But it's moving along nicely

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if we look at block 69392 at https://explorer.myhush.org/block/000000000d74e0020b50096a29204fb2ffdda77ffbde057d974e291ebd68e4e0

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: Nice! I m very excited about that not to have to parse each trx

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: we see it has 1 joinsplit, which counts as 1 zpayment, which was not fully shielded

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @CHMEX have a look at the definitions of things here (don't worry about the low-level C++ stuff) and let me know if stuff makes sense to you: `https://github.com/MyHush/hush3/pull/27/files`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: there are some weird edge cases, but I think I defined things "correctly"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i.e. how many shielded payments is a (z,z,t,t) => (z,t) transaction? That kind of breaks your brain.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: those don't even occur (z_sendmany can't make them) but when raw xtns are easier, they can happen

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: Looks good

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am pretty sure my heuristics are 99.99% correct, most of the time. But I might have some bugs in implementing my heuristics. That needs to be tested

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: soon I will run this on Pirate, which will give me much more data. Running it on HUSH mainnet now

Author: CHMEX#0686
Content: is it very cpu intensive?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: not sure, but my guess is no. I didn't add any new loops

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I just do a few extra integer math ops for every transaction in the chain

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: What is more, is RAM usage

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Let's estimate it's 100 bytes more RAM for every instance of `pindex`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I have no idea how many instances of pindex KMD internals keeps at a time

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: all in all, it's not going to increase RAM drastically. But it could increase it a few megabytes?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it uses no disk space

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: everything is memory-only

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: also, maybe I slowed down transaction validation time a bit, not sure. But that usually is not a bottleneck

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: and that is not quite accurate. I might have slowed down the time it takes for a node to "receive" blocks, not validate xtns. I hooked into the code that receives blocks and keeps stats about taddrs

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: TLDR: I have no idea of performance effects, only guesses üòÉ

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content:
```Why JSON is Better Than XML

XML is much more difficult to parse than JSON.
JSON is parsed into a ready-to-use JavaScript object.

For AJAX applications, JSON is faster and easier than XML:

Using XML

    Fetch an XML document
    Use the XML DOM to loop through the document
    Extract values and store in variables

Using JSON

    Fetch a JSON string
    JSON.Parse the JSON string```
-w3schools.com

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
Yes, thanks for the opinions folks!  try to find JSON standards though!!
I made some initial queries with JSON schemas standardization and parsers, there are two aiming for acceptance as RFC but they offer the implementation with it.

This is a problem because KMD codebase already has 2 JSON parsers, the btc one and one in C for The cryptocondition stuff.

I‚Äôm looking for use cases to interconnect systems.  Currently my best two finds are landxml which is a huge system of data used by surveyors, civil & other engineers, architects and government.  Supported by high tech engineering tools as well as autocad, autodesk etc.

The other is Shopify products and orders.

A third is booking.com and the entire travel industry.

I really want an ‚Äúeasy‚Äù integration example, not so much of a learn a whole discipline to extract a small part of data.

XML standards offer many implementations into legacy systems, payroll, education etc.   JSON little interoperability amongst disparate systems.

It‚Äôs for a CClib example with oracles at the end of the day.  Possibly tokens.  I want to be able to show new levels of interoperability.

Finding a small and useful existing schema with an easy to explain use case üôè
